data.title: Moving To Chile
data.meta_description: Get ready to discover the unique culture, rich history, and stunning landscapes of Chile! Learn more about Moving to Chile from USA now!
data.text:
Known as the southernmost country in the world which is located closest to Antarctica, Chile is a South American nation. The country is famous for its unique culture, rich history, and delicious food.

Chile is also blessed with diverse and stunning landscapes ranging from the Atacama Desert to Patagonia and dotted with mountains, forests, and beaches. The capital city, Santiago, is home to many museums, galleries, and cultural institutions. Chile is also famous for its wine production and is a popular destination for outdoor enthusiasts, with activities such as skiing, hiking,

Chile is also known for having a high-income economy among South American countries making it an ideal destination for expats. The country also ranks high in social safety and boasts of a welcoming population.

Prepare for an international move to Chile from the USA

Chile is one South American country that offers a unique blend of life. The country boasts of a stable economy, has a vibrant cultural scene and stunning landscapes to explore. Moving to Chile from the USA can really be an exciting adventure! Chile offers a unique blend of Latin American culture and modern amenities.

When you move to Chile from the USA you can expect a high quality of life, with a high-income economy and a low cost of living. However, you may need to adjust to a different language and cultural norms. Researching the process and requirements for moving to Chile is essential, including obtaining a visa and finding affordable housing.

Moreover, any international relocation needs proper planning. So, you need to take into consideration the visa processes, securing housing and healthcare and gathering any vital information you can that can help you in a smooth transition after you move to Chile from the USA.

Different types of visas that Chile offers

Chile is one of the most progressive South American countries with a high-income economy. If you want to move to Chile from the USA on work purpose there are different types of visas available.

Let us share some insights –

Tourist Visas

If you are a citizen of any of these countries – the US, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, and EU states, then you will not require a visa for 90 days when you move to Chile. In this case a document called Tarjeta de Turismo or tourist card is issued upon arrival in the country.

However, if you are one of the expats who has decided to visit Chile before an actual relocation or for a fact-finding tour or for searching a job in Chile then you can apply for a tourist visa. You will need to submit the following documents:

Your completed visa application form

A proof that you have booked a flight to Chile and a return ticket

Your valid passport and a photocopy

A certificate of employment or pay slips for the last three months

One passport-sized, biometric photograph with your full name on the back

Proof of a hotel reservation or an invitation from an individual or a company in Chile

Short-term Visas

This is another type of visa that Chile offers. A short-term visa, which is also known as a temporary resident visa is applicable to

Interns with A Chilean organisation

Students on a gap year doing volunteer work

Individuals travelling to Chile for family reunification or visit purposes

Expats on short-term assignments.

The validity of a short-term visa is for a maximum period of one year only. If you are applying for a short-term visa with a tourist visa, note that it may take up to 4 weeks for a short-term visa to be approved.

Work Visas

There are regular work visas that Chile offers to people who are willing to move to Chile from the USA and work in the country. However, before applying for this visa be aware of the process –

You will have to visit the Chilean consulate in the USA to sign the work contract and then have it notarized. For this purpose book an appointment and then pay the necessary fee in advance.

Note that pre-signed work contracts are usually not accepted. Also, your work contract needs to follow Chilean law.

Your Chilean employer needs to visit the Chilean Department of Foreign Affairs in order to have his or her signature notarized.
